explanation: mhd_tool_get_system_cpu_count: detect_cpu_core_count only calls this function (no arguments) and uses its int return; you must inspect its declaration/definition to confirm it does not return or take any pointer(s) whose const-qualification would affect the MISRA pointer rule (e.g. hidden pointer return or out-parameter). mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count: same rationale as above — check its prototype/definition to ensure it does not use or return non-const pointers that would interplay with detect_cpu_core_count and the MISRA const-pointer rule. MHD_REAL_CPU_COUNT: this macro is conditionally used as a fallback; you need its definition/type to confirm it is an integer constant (not a pointer or expression yielding a pointer) and so does not introduce pointer/const-qualification concerns. stdio.h (fprintf, printf, stderr prototypes): detect_cpu_core_count calls fprintf/printf and passes string literals and stderr. To assess MISRA pointer const rules you must see the actual parameter types (fprintf/printf take const char* for format arguments, stderr is a FILE*), so include the stdio prototypes to verify that passing the literals and stderr does not violate the rule (e.g. check that const qualifiers are present where expected).
